metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of the ground-based microwave radiometers and ground truth observations for soil freeze/thaw cycle in the A'rou foci experimental area
metadata.description:
The dataset of the ground-based microwave radiometers and ground truth observations for soil freeze/thaw cycle was obtained in the A'rou foci experimental area (N38º03.639'/E100º26.793'; 2998m) from May 5 to 8, 2008, S-band from Apr. 6 to 8, C-band from Apr. 7 to 8, K-band from Apr. 5 to 8, and Ka-band on Apr. 5, to be specific. The aims of the measurements were the effects of the soil freeze/thaw status on the microwave brightness temperatures. 
     The observation site was bare land and the soil moisture was 30% after artificial irrigation. Observation items included the soil temperature at 5cm automatically (the time interval: 10m), the soil temperature at 5cm, 10cm, 20cm and 30cm by the probe thermometer (the time interval: 1h), and the soil moisture at 5cm, 10cm, 20cm and 30cm automatically (the time interval: 10m). 
     Seven files were included, four ground-based microwave radiometers (S-band, C-band, K-band and Ka-band) observations, the automatic soil temperature, the manual soil temperature, and the automatic soil moisture, and the last three were archived in Excel format.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to observe the impact of soil freeze-thaw conditions on microwave brightness temperature?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to observe the impact of soil freeze-thaw conditions on microwave brightness temperature involves utilizing ground-based microwave radiometers across multiple frequency bands (S, C, K, and Ka) to conduct continuous observations over a flat bare soil area. The method includes maintaining soil moisture levels between approximately 14% and 30% through artificial irrigation and monitoring soil temperature and moisture at various depths using automatic and manual instruments. This comprehensive setup provides essential data for developing microwave radiation transmission forward models and microwave remote sensing inversion models.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics and specifications of ground-based microwave radiometers used for observing soil freeze-thaw states?
Feature Specification.Answer: S-band, C-band, K-band, Ka-band, multi-frequency, multi-polarization, multi-angle continuous observations

Definition.Question: What does '地基微波辐射计' mean in the context of this domain of study?
Definition.Answer: In this domain, '地基微波辐射计' refers to ground-based microwave radiometers that are used for multi-frequency, multi-polarization, and multi-angle continuous observations to study the influence of surface freeze-thaw states on microwave brightness temperature.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of accurately measuring soil moisture and temperature using ground-based microwave radiometers in a frost-thaw environment?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges include the initial dry state of the soil with approximately 14% moisture content, which is later artificially adjusted to around 30% through irrigation, and the need to account for variations in soil moisture and temperature at different depths (5cm, 10cm, 20cm, and 30cm) using both automatic and manual observation methods.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the main objective of conducting ground-based microwave radiometer observations in a flat bare soil area with varying soil moisture levels?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objective is to understand the impact of the freeze-thaw state of the surface on microwave brightness temperature, providing foundational data for developing microwave radiation transmission forward models and microwave remote sensing inversion models for frozen/thawed soils.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to observe the impact of soil freeze-thaw cycles on microwave brightness temperature using ground-based microwave radiometers, and how is the data structured for analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ground-based microwave radiometers are used to conduct continuous observations at multiple frequencies, polarizations, and angles to assess the impact of soil freeze-thaw cycles on microwave brightness temperature. The data is structured in files corresponding to different frequency bands (S, C, K, and Ka), and includes both automatic and manual soil temperature and moisture observations. The soil temperature and moisture data are stored in Excel spreadsheets for further analysis.
